time functions

Function Lists: Time Functions. convsecs() - Converts Unix seconds to a time string. convtime() - Converts a time string to Unix seconds. ptimefmt() - Performs time formatting, PennMUSH style. secs() - Returns the current time in Unix seconds. singletime() - Converts seconds to a single time element. time() - Returns the current time, formatted as a string. timefmt() - Returns the current, or a specified time, formatted.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIME()

Function: time() Gives you the current time. WARNING! This is the time on the machine that the mud is running on, and not where you are. Example: > say time() You say "Thu Dec 19 09:48:06 1991" See Also: convsecs(), convtime(), secs(), msecs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT ADVANCED

The advanced syntax of the timefmt format string adds the ability to do special processing for 0 valued fields. The new format sequence looks like: $[PROCOPT][-][FIELDWIDTH]FORMATSPEC The PROCOPT character is one of the following: '!' - Don't print field if value is 0 '~' - Don't print field if value is 0, but pad w/ spaces to fld width '@' - Only print field if current field value or a previous field value was not 0 '#' - Only print field if current field value or a previous field value was not 0, but pad w/ spaces to fld width If a field is not printed, the copying of any literal text following the format specifier is suppressed until the next format sequence at which point copying is turned back on. You can turn the copying function back on at any point in the literal text which follows a sequence with a PROCOPT by repeating the same PROCOPT character at the point in the literal text which you want copying to be always on. See Also: timefmt advanced2, timefmt advanced example, timefmt escapes
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT ADVANCED EXAMPLE

The following examples take an elapsed time (which is hard coded as the second argument for illustration purposes) and format it in such a way that any fields which are irrelevant are eliminated. Several examples are shown with the same format string and different <secs> argument to illustrate how the output changes depending on this input. Note the '#' character following 'secs' in the format string, this ensures that even if the $#G field is 0 and the 'secs' text is not printed that the ' <-' text will still be printed. timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 111111111) OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 12 days 0 hours 11 mins 51 secs <- timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 11111) OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 3 hours 5 mins 11 secs <- timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 1111) OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 18 mins 31 secs <- Now note how the output changes with the '@' PROCOPT used instead of '#': timefmt(Elapsed -> $@2c days $@2X hours $@2F mins $@G secs@ <-, 1111) OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 18 mins 31 secs <- The '~' and '!' PROCOPT characters operate similarly but they only pay attention to the current field being 0 or not. See Also: timefmt codelist
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT ADVANCED2

With the '~' and '#' PROCOPT types, any literal text which was turned off by a 0 value field will be substituted by spaces. This keeps text aligned in columns. Should one of the PROCOPT characters be needed as a literal text character following a field that contains a PROCOPT, the character can be escaped by doubling it, IE '@@' would print '@' if it was embedded in text which followed a sequence like $@G. See Also: timefmt advanced example, timefmt escapes
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT CODELIST

Following codes exist for formatting for timefmt(<format>,<time-in-secs>) Code Type Range Code Type Range ---- -------------- ------------ ---- -------------- ------------------ H hour of day 1 - 12 A Weekday (long) Sunday - Saturday h military day 0 - 23 a Weekday (short) Sun - Sat T minute in hour 0 - 59 W Weekday (num) 0 - 6 S sec. in min. 0 - 59 B Month (long) January - December P Time of day AM - PM b Month (short) Jan - Dec p Time of day am - pm M Month (number) 1 - 12 Z Elapsed years 0 - ???? D Day of month 1 - 31 E Months in years 0 - 12 J Day of year 1 - 366 e Elapsed months 0 - ???? Y Year (four dig) 0 - ???? C Days in months 0 - 31 y Year (two dig) 0 - ?? d Days in weeks 0 - 6 I Seconds offset from GMT time w Weeks in month 0 - 4 z Returns '1' if daylight savings u Years in century 0 - 99 i Returns the timezone abbreviation U Century in Mill 0 - 9 N Returns the longname of timezone m Elapsed Millenium 0 - ???? n Return the shortname of timezone *c Elapsed days 0 - ???? t Seconds offset of existing timezone *X Hours in day 0 - 24 *! Don't print field if value is 0 x Elapsed hours 0 - ???? ~ Pad with space but not if value 0 *F Mins. in hours 0 - 60 @ Prnt if value or prev. value not 0 f Elapsed mins. 0 - ???? # Pad with spc if val/prev val not 0 G Secs. in minute 0 - 60 *0-9 Format column with # allignment g Elapsed secs. 0 - ???? $ Use special code (this list) Note: Codes with a '*' were used in the example that follows. { help timefmt codelist2 for an example with great details }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT CODELIST2

Syntax: timefmt($<code> $<code> ... $<code>,<time-in-seconds>) Example: ---[timefmt($!2cd$02X:$02F,conn(me))]--- Output: --- 3d12:03--- Description: This tells to format the time and to display the day field only if this value is non-zero, then return the hours and minutes, in a time format (IE: ##:## - the 02 says pad with zeroes a total of two spaces no matter the result). It then passes the total time you were connected (the conn() function) into the format you specified for timefmt(). Broken up, these codes are: Details: $!2cd - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code. ! tells it to not print this field if zero 2c tells it to print a two character field and pad with a space if the value is less than two characters. If you use $!02cd it would return '03d' instead of ' 3d' $02X - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code. 02X tells it to print the hour field and pad with zeroes if the total character count is less than two. IE: '06' $02F - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code. 02F tells it to print the minute field and pad with zeroes if the total character count is less than two. IE: '12'
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT DATE

The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs> argument as calendar time for purposes of displaying dates. Calendar time is the number of seconds since 0:00 1/1/70 such as that returned by the secs() function. SPEC DESC RANGE NOTE 'A' Weekday long name Sunday..Saturday 'a' Weekday short name Sun..Sat 'W' Weekday number 0..6 0 = Sunday 'B' Month long name January..December 'b' Month short name Jan..Dec 'M' Month number 1..12 'D' Day of month 1..31 'J' Day of year 1..366 'Y' Year 0..???? 'y' Year (two digit) 0..99 See Also: timefmt examples, secs(), msecs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT ELAPSED

The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs> argument as elapsed time. An example of elapsed time would be those number of seconds returned by the conn() function. SPEC DESC RANGE NOTE 'm' Elapsed Millenium 0..???? 'U' Elapsed Century in Millenium 0..9 'u' Elapsed years in Century 0..99 'Z' Elapsed years 0..???? Uses 365 day years 'E' Elapsed months in year 0..12 Uses 31 day months/365 days 'e' Elapsed months absolute 0..???? Uses 31 day months 'C' Elapsed days in month 0..31 Uses 31 day months 'w' Elapsed weeks in month 0..4 'd' Elapsed days in week 0..6 'c' Elapsed days absolute 0..???? 'X' Elapsed hours in day 0..24 'x' Elapsed hours absolute 0..???? 'F' Elapsed minutes in hour 0..60 'f' Elapsed minutes absolute 0..???? 'G' Elapsed seconds in minute 0..60 'g' Elapsed seconds absolute 0..???? See Also: timefmt examples, conn()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT ESCAPES

To cause the timefmt function to output a '$' character it must be repeated twice, example: @emit timefmt($$MONEY$$ at $H O'clock,secs()) SAMPLE OUTPUT: $MONEY$ at 3 O'clock ADVANCED TIMEFMT ESCAPES To cause the timefmt function to output a PROCOPT character from within literal text which follows a format sequence which also contains the needed PROCOPT character it must be repeated twice. Otherwise, the character is a special signal to the timefmt function to tell it that even if a field was suppressed due to a 0 value field that you want to override the conditional processing for the literal text which follows the PROCOPT character. Example: @emit timefmt($!g Seconds Elapsed Dude!! Way to go.,conn()) SAMPLE OUTPUT: 5 Seconds Elapsed Dude! Way to go. If the '!' character was not doubled in the above example, and the $g field equated to 0, then the output would go like this: @emit timefmt($!g Seconds Elapsed Dude! Way to go.,0) SAMPLE OUTPUT: Way to go. See Also: timefmt advanced
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT EXAMPLES

Wordy time and date: @emit timefmt($A $B $2D\, $04Y $02H:$02T $P and $02S seconds, secs()) SAMPLE OUTPUT: Monday January 20, 1997 03:05 AM and 55 seconds A week-long calendar starting today including Julian date: @emit nsiter(lnum(7),timefmt($a $b $02D $04Y \\[$04Y.$03J\\], add(secs(),mul(86400,##)))%r) SAMPLE OUTPUT: Mon Jan 20 1997 [1997.020] Tue Jan 21 1997 [1997.021] Wed Jan 22 1997 [1997.022] Thu Jan 23 1997 [1997.023] Fri Jan 24 1997 [1997.024] Sat Jan 25 1997 [1997.025] Sun Jan 26 1997 [1997.026] Mimicking the time() function: @emit timefmt($a $b $2D $02h:$02T:$02S $04Y,secs()) SAMPLE OUTPUT: Mon Jan 20 03:20:39 1997 Elapsed time such as displayed on WHO in 'On For' column: @emit timefmt($!2cd$02X:$02F,conn(me)) SAMPLE OUTPUT: 3d12:03 NOTE: This example uses advanced features, see: help timefmt advanced See Also: timefmt advanced
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT SYNTAX

The timefmt format string can contain two types of data. First it can contain literal text which is mearly copied to the function's output. Second it can contain format sequences. Every format sequence in the format string describes a field to be filled in by the timefmt function. Fields are by default variable width and right justified. A format sequence begins with a '$' character and is followed by an optional left justification character ('-'), a field width, and a mandatory format specifier. The syntax can be described visually as follows: $[-][FIELDWIDTH]FORMATSPEC A field width is specified as a sequence of digits representing the required width of the field. If a field width number begins with a '0' the field will be zero padded, the default is to pad with spaces. An example of a format sequence would be '$-5M' which would print the month name left justified in a field with a width of 5. Should the month name be longer than 5 then the name will be truncated. See Also: timefmt syntax2
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT SYNTAX2

Should it be necessary to use a '$' without wishing it to be interpreted as the start of a format sequence, use two '$' characters in a row as in '$$'. These two will be compressed into one literal '$'. There are other advanced features in the syntax which are not described here so as not to confuse the basic topic. See Also: timefmt, timefmt advanced, timefmt escapes
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT TIME

The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs> argument as calendar time for purposes of displaying the time. Calendar time is the number of seconds since 0:00 1/1/70 such as that returned by the secs() function. SPEC DESC RANGE 'H' Hour of day 1..12 'h' Hour of day 0..23 'T' Minute in hour 0..59 'S' Second in minute 0..59 'P' AM or PM AM/PM 'p' am or pm am/pm See Also: timefmt examples, secs(), msecs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT TIMEZONE

Following are codes used specifically for timezone manipulation and identification. SPEC DESC RANGE NOTE 'z' Daylight Savings Toggle 0..1 Boolean to show if active 't' Offset of MUSH local TZ 0..? Offset in secs of current TZ 'I' Offset from GMT time 0..? Offset in secs from GMT 'i' Abbreviation of Timezone XYZ 'N' Timezone Longname <str> Returns the Timezone Name 'n' Timezone Shortname <str> Returns geographical area See Also: timefmt codelist
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TIMEFMT()

Function: timefmt(<format string>, <secs> [,<output timezone>]) Uses the provided <format string> to output the <secs> in many useful ways. The function can be used to interpret <secs> as calendar time, or as elapsed time. Due to the many capabilities of this function, help for it is broken up into several sections. You may specify an optional output timezone for the time. For a list of timezones, please see 'help timezone list'. ALL AVAILABLE CODES: help timefmt codelist (very handy!) FORMAT SYNTAX: help timefmt syntax TIME FORMATS: help timefmt time DATE FORMATS: help timefmt date ELAPSED TIME FORMATS: help timefmt elapsed EXAMPLES: help timefmt examples ESCAPE SEQUENCES: help timefmt escapes TIMEZONE FORMATS: help timefmt timezone See Also: time(), singletime(), ptimefmt(), timezone list
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TOBIN()

Function: tobin(<number>) Todec converts the inputted number into binary. The following formats are used to send to it: 0x<number> - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 0<number> - used to specify an octal number. (base 8) 0b<number> - used to specify a binary number. (base 2) <number> - used to specify standard decimal. (base 10) Examples: > say tobin(011) You say "00000000000000000000000000001001" > say tobin(3) You say "00000000000000000000000000000011" > say tobin(0x11) You say "00000000000000000000000000010001" See Also: tohex(), tooct(), todec()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TODEC()

Function: todec(<number>) Todec converts the inputted number into decimal. The following formats are used to send to it: 0x<number> - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 0<number> - used to specify an octal number. (base 8) 0b<number> - used to specify a binary number. (base 2) <number> - used to specify standard decimal. (base 10) Examples: > say todec(011) You say "9" > say todec(0b11) You say "3" > say todec(0x11) You say "17" See Also: tohex(), tooct(), tobin()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TOGGLE LIST

Toggle Toggle Toggle ----------------------- ----------------------- ------------------------- MONITOR VANILLA_ERRORS NO_ANSI_EX CPUTIME NOTIFY_LINK NO_ANSI_PLAYER NO_ANSI_THING NO_ANSI_ROOM NO_ANSI_EXIT ZONE_AUTOADD ZONE_AUTOADDALL BRANDY_MAIL EXTANSI PENN_MAIL MAIL_STRIPRETURN VPAGE MAIL_NOPARSE MUXPAGE NOZONEPARENT NOGLOBPARENT VARIABLE KEEPALIVE NOISY ZONECMDCHK ACCENTS MAILVALIDATE SAFELOG For information on a particular toggle, type 'help <togglename>'. If the name of a toggle is similar to the name of another help entry you may need to add the word 'toggle'. As in 'help monitor toggle'. See Also: @toggle
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

toggle()

Function: toggle(<object>,[!]<toggle>) The toggle() function is a side-effect for the @toggle command. It can only be used to set and remove toggles. It follows the same permissions and restrictions of the command. The SIDEFX flag is required to use toggle(). Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled. Example: > @toggle me=vpage Set. > say toggle(me,vpage) You say ""
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TOGGLES

Topic: TOGGLES Toggles may be set on objects to alter the way the mush treats them. They are similar to flags, but are usually of a more minor consequence. To set or unset a toggle, the @toggle command is used. For a list of toggles see 'help toggle list'. See Also: @toggle, toggle list
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TOHEX()

Function: tohex(<number>) Todec converts the inputted number into hexidecimal. The following formats are used to send to it: 0x<number> - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 0<number> - used to specify an octal number. (base 8) 0b<number> - used to specify a binary number. (base 2) <number> - used to specify standard decimal. (base 10) Examples: > say tohex(017) You say "F" > say tohex(0b11) You say "3" > say tohex(-1) You say "FFFFFFFF" See Also: todec(), tooct(), tobin()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TOOCT()

Function: tooct(<number>) Tooct converts the inputted number into octal. The following formats are used to send to it: 0x<number> - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 0<number> - used to specify an octal number. (base 8) 0b<number> - used to specify a binary number. (base 2) <number> - used to specify standard decimal. (base 10) Examples: > say tooct(11) You say "13" > say tooct(0b11) You say "3" > say tooct(0x10) You say "20" See Also: tohex(), todec(), tobin()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]
